overall_score_comment: This song has fewer original thoughts than a motivational poster in a dentist's waiting room.
the_roast:
Let's address the elephant in the room: Dua Lipa discovered the word 'Houdini' and decided to beat it to death like it owed her money. She says 'I come and I go' approximately seventeen thousand times, as if repeating the same four words will somehow manifest depth. News flash: saying you're mysterious doesn't make you mysterious—it makes you sound like that friend who cancels plans last minute and calls it 'being spontaneous.' The entire premise is 'I'm so elusive and hard to pin down,' but she explains this concept so many times that she's basically the opposite of elusive. It's like a magician performing the same disappearing act nine times in a row while loudly announcing 'WATCH ME DISAPPEAR!' You're not Houdini, babe—you're a notification that keeps popping up.

The lyrical crimes here are SPECTACULAR. 'Time is passin' like a solar eclipse'—really? REALLY? Time passes like... a thing that happens once every few years in specific geographic locations? That's not how time works! Time passes like TIME. Every second, consistently, forever. A solar eclipse is literally the worst metaphor for the passage of time because it's rare and brief. You've essentially said 'time is passing like something that barely passes.' Congratulations, you've broken physics and poetry simultaneously. Then we get 'Come in closer, are you readin' my lips?' which sounds like she's at a loud party trying to order a sandwich, not seducing anyone. The desperation in 'prove you got the right to please me' is giving 'show me your resume before I consider this date' energy. This isn't sexy mystique—this is a job interview with commitment issues.

The bridge delivers the killing blow to whatever remained of lyrical integrity: 'Everything you say is soundin' so sweet / But do you practice everything that you preach?' First of all, nobody is PREACHING at you, Dua. This is a date, not a tent revival. Second, this is followed by 'I need something that'll make me believe'—believe WHAT? That you're capable of staying in one place? That clichés are an acceptable substitute for actual content? The vagueness is so thick you could cut it with a knife, if the knife wasn't also too bored to commit. And my personal favorite disaster: 'Maybe you could cause a girl to change her ways.' Oh, so NOW you might stick around? Make up your mind! You've spent three minutes telling us you're going to vanish, and suddenly you're open to changing? Pick a lane! This is more flip-flopping than a politician during election season.

The chorus repeats FOUR TIMES with minimal variation, because apparently the songwriting budget ran out after purchasing the rights to Houdini's name. 'Catch me or I go Houdini' is repeated so often it should come with a free loyalty card—buy nine Houdini references, get the tenth disappearing act free! The whole song is structured like someone who learned about the concept of a 'hook' but misunderstood and thought it meant 'say the same thing until people give up and leave.' Mission accomplished, I guess? The final 'Ooh' and 'Oh-oh' are doing absolutely NOTHING except filling time, like vocal wallpaper. They're the lyrical equivalent of 'um' and 'uh' in a conversation. At least Houdini had the decency to actually disappear—these lyrics just keep coming back like a boomerang nobody asked for.

cliche_counter.cliche: The 'I'm so mysterious and elusive' trope
cliche_counter.quip: Playing hard to get is one thing, but this is playing hard to care about

cliche_counter.cliche: 'Prove yourself worthy of me' power dynamics
cliche_counter.quip: Girl boss energy meets 'please fill out this application in triplicate'

cliche_counter.cliche: The 'maybe you'll make me stay' wishy-washy conditional love
cliche_counter.quip: Nothing says romance like an escape clause and a non-commitment disclaimer

cliche_counter.cliche: 'Practice what you preach' as if this is a theological debate
cliche_counter.quip: Ma'am, this is a Wendy's, not a sermon on commitment

cliche_counter.cliche: Repeating the title/hook ad nauseam as 'songwriting'
cliche_counter.quip: Ctrl+C, Ctrl+V is not a lyrical strategy, it's a cry for help

cliche_counter.cliche: Asking if someone thinks about you 'night and day'
cliche_counter.quip: The only thing less original than this line is a fortune cookie

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Time is passin' like a solar eclipse
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Catastrophic failure of basic metaphor construction and understanding of temporal physics
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Mandatory retake of 8th grade science and a creative writing course taught by anyone with a functioning brain

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: I come and I go (repeated 847 times)
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Aggravated assault on the concept of variety; excessive use of copy-paste without a license
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Forced to write 500 unique lines about the same concept without repetition, like a lyrical detention

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Prove you got the right to please me
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Turning romance into a bureaucratic approval process
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Must attend speed dating events while carrying a clipboard and rating system until understanding human connection

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: But do you practice everything that you preach?
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Misdemeanor misuse of idiom; nobody was preaching, this is not church
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Community service listening to actual preachers to learn what preaching is

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Maybe you could cause a girl to change her ways
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Contradiction of entire song premise; flip-flopping worse than a fish on a dock
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Required to pick ONE personality trait and stick with it for an entire song

hidden_meanings: This is clearly a deep meditation on quantum physics and Schrödinger's commitment—Dua Lipa exists in a superposition of both coming AND going until someone observes her, at which point the waveform collapses into disappointment. The solar eclipse metaphor is actually genius because just like an eclipse, this song briefly blocks out the light of better music, causes temporary confusion about what's happening, and leaves you wondering why you looked directly at it.
final_verdict: This song is what happens when someone discovers the thesaurus entry for 'elusive' was just the same word written six times. Houdini escaped from chains and water tanks; these lyrics couldn't escape from a paper bag with a map and a flashlight.
title: Houdini
